subject: polity
title: Parliamentary vs Presidential System - Comprehensive Comparison

rows.parliamentary: **Dual executive**: Nominal head (President/Monarch) + Real head (Prime Minister/Cabinet)
rows.presidential: **Single executive**: President is both Head of State and Head of Government

rows.parliamentary: **President/Monarch** - Nominal/Ceremonial head; Acts on advice of Council of Ministers (Art 74 in India)
rows.presidential: **President** - Real executive authority; Makes decisions independently

rows.parliamentary: **Prime Minister** - Real executive power; Leader of majority party; Heads Council of Ministers
rows.presidential: **President** - Same person is both Head of State and Government

rows.parliamentary: **PM from Legislature**: Leader of majority party in Parliament becomes PM; Indirect selection by people
rows.presidential: **President directly elected**: Separate election for President (Electoral College in USA); Direct mandate from people

rows.parliamentary: **Ministers ARE members** of Parliament (Art 75(5) - India); PM and Ministers must be MPs
rows.presidential: **President is NOT member** of Congress; Cannot be Congressman; Separation of persons

rows.parliamentary: **Unfixed term**: PM's term depends on confidence of Lok Sabha; Can be removed anytime by no-confidence (Art 75(3)); May continue entire 5 years or fall earlier
rows.presidential: **Fixed term**: President has fixed term (4 years in USA, 5 in France); Cannot be removed easily (only impeachment for serious offenses)

rows.parliamentary: **Collective responsibility** (Art 75(3)): Council of Ministers collectively responsible to Lok Sabha; Must enjoy confidence; If no-confidence passed, entire Council resigns
rows.presidential: **No collective responsibility**: President not responsible to Legislature; No concept of vote of confidence/no-confidence

rows.parliamentary: **PM can dissolve** lower house (Lok Sabha in India, House of Commons in UK) and call fresh elections (on PM's advice - Art 85)
rows.presidential: **Cannot dissolve**: President cannot dissolve Congress; Congress completes full term

rows.parliamentary: **Fusion of powers**: Executive (PM/Ministers) is part of Legislature (Parliament); No strict separation; Executive emerges from Legislature
rows.presidential: **Strict separation**: Executive (President) and Legislature (Congress) are separate; No overlapping membership; Checks and balances

rows.parliamentary: **Easy removal**: No-confidence motion (Art 75(3)); Simple majority in Lok Sabha can remove PM/Council of Ministers anytime
rows.presidential: **Difficult removal**: Only **impeachment** for violation of Constitution/serious offenses; 2/3rd majority needed; Rarely successful

rows.parliamentary: **Cabinet is real executive**: Council of Ministers (Art 74) headed by PM; Collective decision-making; PM is 'first among equals'
rows.presidential: **Cabinet is advisory**: President appoints Cabinet/Secretaries; But President takes final decisions; Not collective; President supreme

rows.parliamentary: **Requires majority party/coalition**: PM must have majority in Lok Sabha; Hung Parliament can paralyze government; Coalition govts common
rows.presidential: **Can work with divided govt**: President from one party, Congress majority from another - Can function (checks and balances)

rows.parliamentary: **Less stable**: Govt can fall anytime if loses majority (no-confidence); Frequent govt changes possible (Italy, India pre-1990s); Coalition govts unstable
rows.presidential: **More stable**: President has fixed term; Cannot be removed easily; Govt stability assured for full term

rows.parliamentary: **More flexible**: Govt can be changed quickly if inefficient (no-confidence); Fresh elections possible; Responsive to public opinion
rows.presidential: **Less flexible**: Stuck with President for full term even if inefficient; Cannot be changed except impeachment (very difficult)

rows.parliamentary: **Executive controls legislature**: PM/Ministers are majority in Parliament; Can easily pass Bills (party discipline); Opposition weak
rows.presidential: **Independent legislature**: Congress independent of President; Can reject President's Bills; Checks President's power; Stronger legislature

rows.parliamentary: **Weak checks**: Since executive is part of legislature (fusion), difficult to check executive; Opposition is main check
rows.presidential: **Strong checks**: Executive and Legislature check each other; Judicial review strong; Real balance of power

rows.parliamentary: **Better representation**: Ministers are MPs; Direct contact with people's representatives; Questions/debates in Parliament (Art 75(5))
rows.presidential: **Less direct representation**: President/Cabinet not in Congress; Less direct contact with Legislature; Communication formal

rows.parliamentary: **Collective**: Cabinet/Council of Ministers collectively decide (Cabinet collective responsibility); Consensus-based; PM coordinates
rows.presidential: **Individual**: President takes final decisions; Cabinet advises but President decides; Faster decisions possible

rows.parliamentary: **Slower**: Collective decision-making; Cabinet approval needed; PM must carry Cabinet; May delay in crisis
rows.presidential: **Faster**: President can act quickly (Commander-in-Chief); No need for collective approval; Better for crisis management

rows.parliamentary: **High accountability**: Daily Question Hour (India Art 75(6)); Ministers answer to Parliament; Debates; Scrutiny; Vulnerable to no-confidence
rows.presidential: **Lower accountability**: President not answerable to Congress day-to-day; No Question Hour; Less scrutiny; Fixed term provides immunity

rows.parliamentary: **Homogeneous societies**: Where political parties strong; Stable majorities possible; UK, India, Canada, Australia, Japan
rows.presidential: **Diverse societies**: Where checks needed on executive; USA, Brazil, Indonesia, Philippines

rows.parliamentary:
• Better coordination (executive + legislature)
• More accountable (no-confidence)
• Flexible (can change govt)
• Better representation (Ministers are MPs)
• Collective wisdom (Cabinet)
rows.presidential:
• More stable (fixed term)
• Strong checks (separation of powers)
• Quick decisions (single executive)
• No legislative paralysis (divided govt can function)
• Clear mandate (direct election)

rows.parliamentary:
• Less stable (no-confidence)
• Fusion may lead to executive dominance
• Weak opposition
• Coalition instability
• PM not directly elected
rows.presidential:
• Less accountable (fixed term)
• Slow legislation (checks)
• Divided govt deadlocks
• No collective wisdom
• Less flexible (stuck with President)

rows.parliamentary: **UK** (Westminster model - origin), **India**, **Canada**, **Australia**, **Japan**, **Germany**, **Italy**, **Spain**, **Malaysia**
rows.presidential: **USA** (original model), **Brazil**, **Indonesia**, **Philippines**, **Nigeria**, **South Korea**, **France** (Semi-presidential)

rows.presidential: **France**: President (directly elected, real power) + PM (from Parliament); Both have executive powers; Mix of Parliamentary and Presidential

indianParliamentarySystem: **Art 74**: Council of Ministers headed by PM to **aid and advise** President
**Art 75(3)**: Council of Ministers **collectively responsible** to Lok Sabha
**Art 75(5)**: Ministers must be MPs (or become MP within 6 months)
**Art 85**: President can dissolve Lok Sabha (on PM's advice)
**Borrowed from UK**: Westminster model (British Parliamentary system)
whyIndiaBorrowed: **Dr. Ambedkar's reasoning**: India familiar with parliamentary system (British rule); Continuity better than sudden change to Presidential
**Accountability**: Parliamentary system ensures accountability to people's representatives
**Diverse country**: Presidential system may lead to dictatorship in diverse country like India; Parliamentary system safer
**Collective wisdom**: Cabinet collective responsibility ensures decisions are well-deliberated
criticisms: **Instability**: India faced many unstable govts (1989-99 - 6 PMs in 10 years); Coalitions collapsed
**PM dominance**: When single party majority, PM becomes too powerful (no real checks) - Rajiv Gandhi (1984-89), Modi (2014-19, 2019-24)
**Party system breakdown**: Anti-defection law (10th Schedule) has made MPs rubber stamps; No independent thinking
**Non-serious opposition**: Opposition often disrupts Parliament instead of constructive debate
presidentialDebate: **Demand for Presidential system**: Some argue India needs Presidential for stability, quick decisions
**Against**: Parliamentary system ensures accountability; Presidential may lead to authoritarianism in India
**Nehru-Sardar Patel debate (1947-48)**: Patel favored Presidential; Nehru favored Parliamentary - Parliamentary won
**Current**: Parliamentary system part of **basic structure** (cannot be changed) - S.R. Bommai (1994)
drAmbedkarView: **Constituent Assembly Debates**: Dr. Ambedkar defended Parliamentary system:
• Presidential system may lead to dictatorship in India (American system evolved over 200 years; India cannot replicate overnight)
• Parliamentary system ensures executive accountable to Legislature (people's representatives)
usaSystem: **President**: Elected by Electoral College; 4-year term; Max 2 terms (22nd Amendment)
**Cabinet**: Appointed by President (Senate approval); Advises President but President decides
**Congress**: Senate (100 - 2 per state) + House of Representatives (435 - population-based); Cannot be dissolved
**No-confidence**: Not possible; Impeachment only (high crimes and misdemeanors)
**Veto**: President can veto Congress Bills; Congress can override with 2/3rd majority
examTips: **Most asked**: 10-15 points comparison; Then explain which system better for India
**Remember**: **Parliamentary** = Fusion, Collective responsibility, PM from Parliament, No-confidence, Flexible, Less stable
**Remember**: **Presidential** = Separation, No collective responsibility, Direct election, Fixed term, Stable, Less flexible
**India**: Parliamentary system (Art 74, 75) - Borrowed from UK (Westminster model)
**Why India chose**: Familiarity, Accountability, Diverse country (Presidential risky), Dr. Ambedkar's reasoning
**Criticism**: Instability (coalitions), PM dominance (single party majority), Anti-defection (MPs rubber stamps)
**Presidential demand**: Some argue for stability; But Parliamentary is **basic structure** (cannot be changed)

data.summary: **Parliamentary vs Presidential**: **Parliamentary** (India, UK) = Dual executive (President nominal, PM real), PM from Parliament, Collective responsibility (Art 75(3)), No-confidence can remove govt, PM can dissolve Lok Sabha, Fusion of powers, Flexible but less stable, More accountable. **Presidential** (USA) = Single executive (President both Head of State + Govt), Direct election, Fixed term, Separation of powers, Strong checks, Stable but less flexible, Less accountable. **India's choice**: Parliamentary (Art 74, 75) - Borrowed from UK (Westminster model). **Why?** Familiarity (British rule), Accountability, Diverse country (Presidential risky), Dr. Ambedkar's reasoning. **Criticism**: Instability (coalitions), PM dominance, Anti-defection. **Parliamentary system part of basic structure** (S.R. Bommai 1994) - Cannot be changed.
